body.p: To His Excellency The Governor of Kentucky

Your memorialist Adam Benther a citizen of Louisville would respectfully represent that at the March Term 1860 of the City Court of Louisville he was fined the sum of Fifty Dollars and cost for an alledged assault made upon one Protas Nutton. The case had been continued on the Docket until the cost amounted to Nine 40/100 Dollars exclusive of the attorneys portion of the fine. The party assaulted is a member of a cabinet maker Society with your Petitioner, who provoked the assault and was not seriously hurt, only receiving a slight scratch on the hand -- Your Petitioner represents further that he viewed the matter in so trivial a light that he did not attend to the case and moreover paid to Mr Nutto Eight Dollars and a half for the injury he sustained and made friends with him -- The fine is an exorbitant one, so much so that it will be oppressive to your Petitioner to pay the same, as he is poor and a man of family, and a working Mechanic
and the vindication of the law does not call for oppression upon the citizen.

In view of all the facts in this case he respectfully prays a remission of that portion of said fine belonging to the Commonwealth. He has with great inconvenience to himself and family paid all the cost in the case

And will ever pray &c
A Benther
The undersigned respectfully recommend that ^the^ prayer of the foregoing Petition be granted, believing that the case is a meritorious one --

Jacob. Ruckstuhl,
Nicholas Miller
Daniel Grind,
D Denharet
George H Hoppman
Charles Schuster
John A Cummins
F C. Slump
I understand I from a Sen Reliable Source that the Petitioner is a Sobe and industrious man and German and the facts Stated in his Petition are true.

Jas Croxton
J L Hyatt
Chas Miller
Petition of A Renther for a remission of his fine of $50
